commits.commitMessage:
QTI9X06-156 - Use hardware derived storage key for QTEE PA

Instead of using hardcoded plaintext root protection key,
derive the key from hardware key using QTEE KDF function.

Change-Id: I3acf219e0e09ada632c87e314ddbad55fd789a5f
Signed-off-by: Brad Du <bdu@sierrawireless.com>
commits.subject: QTI9X06-156 - Use hardware derived storage key for QTEE PA

comments.message: const char *context = "iotkeystorecntx";
Done
Will this value change depending on whether or not Secure Boot is enabled?

That is the chip serial number and will not change.
However in the below qsee_kdf(NULL will use the hardware key and that hardware key can be the dummy key if secure is not enabled (similar to SFS).
"const void *" according to qsee_kdf.h
removed the force cast.
Are we wanting to print an error unconditionally? Or should this only occur if ret != 0?
That was more for debug. Changed to only print if error
can add 'const'
Done

So the restriction here is that we cannot use the keystore until Secure Boot is enabled, correct? And if debug is re-enabled then does that mean the keystore contents cannot be read and things like IMA and DM Verity would fail?

yes, similar to SFS. I think that makes sense. Otherwise JTAG can be used to peek the keys in TZ APP. Also we don't want to add keys to keystore before environment is secure and secure boot is enabled. However in future we might want to add more logic to not allowing keys to be added before secure boot is enabled if set so.
For IMA and DM verity, it is only public key or hash and encryption might not be required. We are talking if the digests/hash should be stored in plaintext in keystore and maybe this is another reason to do it. For these keys, we are not even sure if this keystore can be used to store these startup keys since keystore is not loaded yet.
In any case, certain security features will fail if debug is re-enabled and that is something we need to watch for.
no longer valid
These notes and headers have been updated long time ago. Please refer to latest revision.

so the size of data len is infolen + 1.

comments.message:
I was having some issues on this call for RPC. The const string pointer returned from TZ might not be valid or accessible to user space.
Is it possible to make it similar to this new API iks_GetVersionStr
(
    char*           bufPtr,         ///< [OUT] Buffer to hold the string.
    size_t          bufSize         ///< [IN] Buffer size.
)

I think in general the IPC layer should be able to handle this type of function call by copying the data across.

But in this case, since the function does not depend on anything in the key store itself.  I'll make this a static inline function so no IPC is required.
shall we add a NULL pointer check for bufPtr?
Done
this local var (multiple KBs) might be too big for some embedded environments.
Yes, this is driven mostly by the size of the RSA keys so there isn't really a way around this.  Let's leave this for now and come up with a way to configure the set of algorithms supported.

Code looks good for PoC.

Do you have provision for supporting different “secret” for different key owner (SWI vs Customers)? 

To maximize code reuse for final product and easy to understand, I recommend following change:
1. Consolidate all .h files under /api into one API file for EXTERNAL to access to keystore for single view of keystore on external API.
2. Create a configure file for all MACRO that can be changed by EXTERNAL without impacting keystore functionality
3. Create clear interface for services that need for supporting keystore such as secure storage (can be pure SW, secure FS API from TZ, etc.), crypto services, etc. This will help production team to identify the porting effort.

Thanks,
Kim Tran

No, as I describe in the Confluence page, this can be achieved either through upper layer access control mechanisms or by running multiple instances of the KeyStore.

 >

 > EXTERNAL to access to keystore for single view of keystore on
 > external API.

Sure, I will add this.

 > 2. Create a configure file for all MACRO that can be changed by
 > EXTERNAL without impacting keystore functionality

MACROs shouldn't be defined externally but I understand your point.

 > 3. Create clear interface for services that need for supporting
 > keystore such as secure storage (can be pure SW, secure FS API from
 > TZ, etc.), crypto services, etc. This will help production team to
 > identify the porting effort.

I had considered writing a platform abstraction layer but nearly the entire implementation is platform specific and depends on things like the file system interface, if there even is a file system, interface to the hardware root key, interface to the OTP fuses, interface to the crypto engine, interface to the TRNG, etc.

 > 
 > Thanks,
 > Kim Tran

commits.commitMessage:
Create KeyStore API, Tool and PoC.

 - Removed all support for OTP keys/digest as they are of uncertain value.
 - Addressed review comments.
 - Added integrity check of challenge files.
 - Updated documentation comments.
 - Moved some KeyStore folders around.

Change-Id: I8be34a5c66b3104db1bb595193c35b0d444cb01e
commits.subject: Create KeyStore API, Tool and PoC.

comments.message: should be 'must also'?
Done
This can be clarified that the same nonce is used during the session. Otherwise it can be misleading that each _Encrypt call will need a new nonce.
I would think that this is self evident as the ks_chachaPoly_Encrypt() function does not take a nonce value.
General: these APIs are not implemented. When pushing these features to platforms, these sub features are likely moved out to later phases.
keystore.h include should not be here since dll provides utility functions to keystore.
keystore.h is internal and is just a collection of commonly used includes.  I think this is fine as the include guards will prevent any circular dependencies.

Based on the underlying sorting order of readdir, the hash can be different if backend store entries are sorted differently.
This is also different than the doc that both ID and tag will be hashed.

Yes, this code is already outdated :)

I will fix this to match the confluence page which will also solve the sort order problem.
general: the file operation to access storage will likely need to be modified for different platforms. We might want to move these functions out to a dedicated adaption layer.
Yes, I had considered writing an adaption layer but the majority of this file is platform dependent so it didn't seem worthwhile.
the nonce cannot be a constant value, right?
In, GCM mode only, the nonce is chosen internally not provided by the caller so no it is not constant.
why not also write the key ID to the storage?

In this case, the key ID is included in the file name which makes searching unnecessary.  If there is no file system then the key ID could be part of the data and a searching algorithm could be used to find the desired key.  Note that the key ID is not secret but is included as AAD.
The WriteToFuse API need to be adapted for certain platforms. It can be moved to a adaption layer so that developer knows what to expect when implement/adapt.
ok
digest related functions need to be implemented.

Before setting the new update key, do we need to check that:
- update key has a valid key value (valuePtr is not NULL)
- update key to update key (update key shouldn't be freely updatable)
This is a very good point!  I will add this.
before writing to back end, do we need to check if update key is already saved to back end?
This should be covered by checking that the update key is not freely updatable as described in your previous comment.
do we need to check if previous extractKey is set or that doesn't matter?
I don't think that matters because the extraction key can be updated while there is no update key.

Related comment: once extractKey ID is set and updateKey is set, there is no way to update extractKey ID, right? I am thinking the case that everybody was initially set to use a common extractKey ID and later some keys want to set to use a different extractKey ID.

That is correct.  For the situation you described I planned to force a delete and recreation of those keys.  This is of course a non atomic operation but I think the situation is very rare.  It is a similar situation to changing the key size.
